Foreign Field Multiplication

This document is an original RFC explaining how we constrain foreign field multiplication (i.e. non-native field multiplication) in the Kimchi proof system. For a more recent RFC, see FFmul RFC.

Changelog

Author(s)DateDetails
Joseph Spadavecchia and Anais QuerolOctober 2022Design of foreign field multiplication in Kimchi

Overview​

This gate constrains

a⋅b=cmod  fa \cdot b = c \mod fa⋅b=cmodf

where a,b,c∈Ffa, b, c \in \mathbb{F_f}a,b,c∈Ff​, a foreign field with modulus fff, using the native field Fn\mathbb{F_n}Fn​ with prime modulus nnn.

Approach​

In foreign field multiplication the foreign field modulus fff could be bigger or smaller than the native field modulus nnn. When the foreign field modulus is bigger, then we need to emulate foreign field multiplication by splitting the foreign field elements up into limbs that fit into the native field element size. When the foreign modulus is smaller everything can be constrained either in the native field or split up into limbs.

Since our projected use cases are when the foreign field modulus is bigger (more on this below) we optimize our design around this scenario. For this case, not only must we split foreign field elements up into limbs that fit within the native field, but we must also operate in a space bigger than the foreign field. This is because we check the multiplication of two foreign field elements by constraining its quotient and remainder. That is, renaming ccc to rrr, we must constrain

a⋅b=q⋅f+r,a \cdot b = q \cdot f + r,a⋅b=q⋅f+r,

where the maximum size of qqq and rrr is f−1f - 1f−1 and so we have

a⋅b≤(f−1)⏟q⋅f+(f−1)⏟r≤f2−1.\begin{aligned} a \cdot b &\le \underbrace{(f - 1)}_q \cdot f + \underbrace{(f - 1)}_r \\ &\le f^2 - 1. \end{aligned}a⋅b​≤q(f−1)​​⋅f+r(f−1)​​≤f2−1.​

Thus, the maximum size of the multiplication is quadratic in the size of foreign field.

Naïve approach

Naïvely, this implies that we have elements of size f2−1f^2 - 1f2−1 that must split them up into limbs of size at most n−1n - 1n−1. For example, if the foreign field modulus is 256256256 and the native field modulus is 255255255 bits, then we'd need log⁡2((2256)2−1)≈512\log_2((2^{256})^2 - 1) \approx 512log2​((2256)2−1)≈512 bits and, thus, require 512/255≈3512/255 \approx 3512/255≈3 native limbs. However, each limb cannot consume all 255255255 bits of the native field element because we need space to perform arithmetic on the limbs themselves while constraining the foreign field multiplication. Therefore, we need to choose a limb size that leaves space for performing these computations.

Later in this document (see the section entitled "Choosing the limb configuration") we determine the optimal number of limbs that reduces the number of rows and gates required to constrain foreign field multiplication. This results in ℓ=88\ell = 88ℓ=88 bits as our optimal limb size. In the section about intermediate products we place some upperbounds on the number of bits required when constraining foreign field multiplication with limbs of size ℓ\ellℓ thereby proving that the computations can fit within the native field size.

Observe that by combining the naïve approach above with a limb size of 888888 bits, we would require 512/88≈6512/88 \approx 6512/88≈6 limbs for representing foreign field elements. Each limb is stored in a witness cell (a native field element). However, since each limb is necessarily smaller than the native field element size, it must be copied to the range-check gate to constrain its value. Since Kimchi only supports 7 copyable witness cells per row, this means that only one foreign field element can be stored per row. This means a single foreign field multiplication would consume at least 4 rows (just for the operands, quotient and remainder). This is not ideal because we want to limit the number of rows for improved performance.

Chinese remainder theorem

Fortunately, we can do much better than this, however, by leveraging the chinese remainder theorem (CRT for short) as we will now show. The idea is to reduce the number of bits required by constraining our multiplication modulo two coprime moduli: 2t2^t2t and nnn. By constraining the multiplication with both moduli the CRT guarantees that the constraints hold with the bigger modulus 2t⋅n2^t \cdot n2t⋅n.

The advantage of this approach is that constraining with the native modulus nnn is very fast, allowing us to speed up our non-native computations. This practically reduces the costs to constraining with limbs over 2t2^t2t, where ttt is something much smaller than 512512512.

For this to work, we must select a value for ttt that is big enough. That is, we select ttt such that 2t⋅n>f2−12^t \cdot n > f^2 - 12t⋅n>f2−1. As described later on in this document, by doing so we reduce the number of bits required for our use cases to 264264264. With 888888 bit limbs this means that each foreign field element only consumes 333 witness elements, and that means the foreign field multiplication gate now only consumes 222 rows. The section entitled "Choosing ttt" describes this in more detail.

Overall approach

Bringing it all together, our approach is to verify that

a⋅b=q⋅f+r\begin{aligned} a \cdot b = q \cdot f + r \end{aligned}a⋅b=q⋅f+r​

over Z+\mathbb{Z^+}Z+. In order to do this efficiently we use the CRT, which means that the equation holds mod M=2t⋅nM = 2^t \cdot nM=2t⋅n. For the equation to hold over the integers we must also check that each side of the equation is less than 2t⋅n2^t \cdot n2t⋅n.

The overall steps are therefore

  1. Apply CRT to equation (1)
    • Check validity with binary modulus mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t
    • Check validity with native modulus mod  n\mod nmodn
  2. Check each side of equation (1) is less than MMM
    • a⋅b<2t⋅na \cdot b < 2^t \cdot na⋅b<2t⋅n
    • q⋅f+r<2t⋅nq \cdot f + r < 2^t \cdot nq⋅f+r<2t⋅n

This then implies that

a⋅b=cmod  f.a \cdot b = c \mod f.a⋅b=cmodf.

where c=rc = rc=r. That is, aaa multiplied with bbb is equal to ccc where a,b,c∈Ffa,b,c \in \mathbb{F_f}a,b,c∈Ff​. There is a lot more to each of these steps. That is the subject of the rest of this document.

Other strategies

Within our overall approach, aside from the CRT, we also use a number of other strategies to reduce the number and degree of constraints.

  • Avoiding borrows and carries
  • Intermediate product elimination
  • Combining multiplications

The rest of this document describes each part in detail.

Parameter selection​

This section describes important parameters that we require and how they are computed.

  • Native field modulus nnn
  • Foreign field modulus fff
  • Binary modulus 2t2^t2t
  • CRT modulus 2t⋅n2^t \cdot n2t⋅n
  • Limb size in bits ℓ\ellℓ

Choosing ttt​

Under the hood, we constrain a⋅b=q⋅f+rmod  2t⋅na \cdot b = q \cdot f + r \mod 2^t \cdot na⋅b=q⋅f+rmod2t⋅n. Since this is a multiplication in the foreign field fff, the maximum size of qqq and rrr are f−1f - 1f−1, so this means

a⋅b≤(f−1)⋅f+(f−1)≤f2−1.\begin{aligned} a \cdot b &\le (f - 1) \cdot f + (f - 1) \\ &\le f^2 - 1. \end{aligned}a⋅b​≤(f−1)⋅f+(f−1)≤f2−1.​

Therefore, we need the modulus 2t⋅n2^t \cdot n2t⋅n such that

2t⋅n>f2−1,2^t \cdot n > f^2 - 1,2t⋅n>f2−1,

which is the same as saying, given fff and nnn, we must select ttt such that

2t⋅n≥f2t≥2log⁡2(f)−log⁡2(n).\begin{aligned} 2^t \cdot n &\ge f^2 \\ t &\ge 2\log_2(f) - \log_2(n). \end{aligned}2t⋅nt​≥f2≥2log2​(f)−log2​(n).​

Thus, we have an lower bound on ttt.

Instead of dynamically selecting ttt for every nnn and fff combination, we fix a ttt that will work for the different selections of nnn and fff relevant to our use cases.

To guide us, from above we know that

tmin=2log⁡2(f)−log⁡2(n)t_{min} = 2\log_2(f) - \log_2(n)tmin​=2log2​(f)−log2​(n)

and we know the field moduli for our immediate use cases.

vesta     = 2^254 + 45560315531506369815346746415080538113 (255 bits)
pallas    = 2^254 + 45560315531419706090280762371685220353 (255 bits)
secp256k1 = 2^256 - 2^32 - 2^9 - 2^8 - 2^7 - 2^6 - 2^4 - 1 (256 bits)

So we can create a table

nnnffftmint_{min}tmin​
vestasecp256k1258
pallassecp256k1258
vestapallas255
pallasvesta255

and know that to cover our use cases we need t≥258t \ge 258t≥258.

Next, given our native modulus nnn and ttt, we can compute the maximum foreign field modulus supported. Actually, we compute the maximum supported bit length of the foreign field modulus f=2mf=2^mf=2m.

2t⋅n≥f2≥(2m)2=22mt+log⁡2(n)>log⁡2(22m)=2m\begin{aligned} 2^t \cdot n &\ge f^2 \\ &\ge (2^m)^2 = 2^{2m} \\ t + \log_2(n) &> \log_2(2^{2m}) = 2m \end{aligned}2t⋅nt+log2​(n)​≥f2≥(2m)2=22m>log2​(22m)=2m​

So we get

mmax=t+log⁡2(n)2.m_{max} = \frac{t + \log_2(n)}{2}.mmax​=2t+log2​(n)​.

With t=258,n=255t=258, n=255t=258,n=255 we have

mmax=258+2552=256.5,\begin{aligned} m_{max} &= \frac{258 + 255}{2} = 256.5, \end{aligned}mmax​​=2258+255​=256.5,​

which is not enough space to handle anything larger than 256 bit moduli. Instead, we will use t=264t=264t=264, giving mmax=259m_{max} = 259mmax​=259 bits.

The above formula is useful for checking the maximum number of bits supported of the foreign field modulus, but it is not useful for computing the maximum foreign field modulus itself (because 2mmax2^{m_{max}}2mmax​ is too coarse). For these checks, we can compute our maximum foreign field modulus more precisely with

maxmod=⌊2t⋅n⌋.max_{mod} = \lfloor \sqrt{2^t \cdot n} \rfloor.maxmod​=⌊2t⋅n​⌋.

The max prime foreign field modulus satisfying the above inequality for both Pallas and Vesta is 926336713898529563388567880069503262826888842373627227613104999999999999999607.

Choosing the limb configuration​

Choosing the right limb size and the right number of limbs is a careful balance between the number of constraints (i.e. the polynomial degree) and the witness length (i.e. the number of rows). Because one limiting factor that we have in Kimchi is the 12-bit maximum for range check lookups, we could be tempted to introduce 12-bit limbs. However, this would mean having many more limbs, which would consume more witness elements and require significantly more rows. It would also increase the polynomial degree by increasing the number of constraints required for the intermediate products (more on this later).

We need to find a balance between the number of limbs and the size of the limbs. The limb configuration is dependent on the value of ttt and our maximum foreign modulus (as described in the previous section). The larger the maximum foreign modulus, the more witness rows we will require to constrain the computation. In particular, each limb needs to be constrained by the range check gate and, thus, must be in a copyable (i.e. permuteable) witness cell. We have at most 7 copyable cells per row and gates can operate on at most 2 rows, meaning that we have an upperbound of at most 14 limbs per gate (or 7 limbs per row).

As stated above, we want the foreign field modulus to fit in as few rows as possible and we need to constrain operands a,ba, ba,b, the quotient qqq and remainder rrr. Each of these will require cells for each limb. Thus, the number of cells required for these is

cells=4⋅limbscells = 4 \cdot limbscells=4⋅limbs

It is highly advantageous for performance to constrain foreign field multiplication with the minimal number of gates. This not only helps limit the number of rows, but also to keep the gate selector polynomial small. Because of all of this, we aim to constrain foreign field multiplication with a single gate (spanning at most 222 rows). As mentioned above, we have a maximum of 14 permuteable cells per gate, so we can compute the maximum number of limbs that fit within a single gate like this.

limbsmax=⌊cells/4⌋=⌊14/4⌋=3\begin{aligned} limbs_{max} &= \lfloor cells/4 \rfloor \\ &= \lfloor 14/4 \rfloor \\ &= 3 \\ \end{aligned}limbsmax​​=⌊cells/4⌋=⌊14/4⌋=3​

Thus, the maximum number of limbs possible in a single gate configuration is 3.

Using limbsmax=3limbs_{max}=3limbsmax​=3 and t=264t=264t=264 that covers our use cases (see the previous section), we are finally able to derive our limbs size

ℓ=tlimbsmax=264/3=88\begin{aligned} \ell &= \frac{t}{limbs_{max}} \\ &= 264/3 \\ &= 88 \end{aligned}ℓ​=limbsmax​t​=264/3=88​

Therefore, our limb configuration is:

  • Limb size ℓ=88\ell = 88ℓ=88 bits
  • Number of limbs is 333

Avoiding borrows​

When we constrain a⋅b−q⋅f=rmod  2ta \cdot b - q \cdot f = r \mod 2^ta⋅b−q⋅f=rmod2t we want to be as efficient as possible.

Observe that the expansion of a⋅b−q⋅fa \cdot b - q \cdot fa⋅b−q⋅f into limbs would also have subtractions between limbs, requiring our constraints to account for borrowing. Dealing with this would create undesired complexity and increase the degree of our constraints.

In order to avoid the possibility of subtractions we instead use a⋅b+q⋅f′a \cdot b + q \cdot f'a⋅b+q⋅f′ where

f′=−fmod  2t=2t−f\begin{aligned} f' &= -f \mod 2^t \\ &= 2^t - f \end{aligned}f′​=−fmod2t=2t−f​

The negated modulus f′f'f′ becomes part of our gate coefficients and is not constrained because it is publicly auditable.

Using the substitution of the negated modulus, we now must constrain a⋅b+q⋅f′=rmod  2ta \cdot b + q \cdot f' = r \mod 2^ta⋅b+q⋅f′=rmod2t.

Observe that f′<2tf' < 2^tf′<2t since f<2tf < 2^tf<2t and that f′>ff' > ff′>f when f<2t−1f < 2^{t - 1}f<2t−1.

Intermediate products​

This section explains how we expand our constraints into limbs and then eliminate a number of extra terms.

We must constrain a⋅b+q⋅f′=rmod  2ta \cdot b + q \cdot f' = r \mod 2^ta⋅b+q⋅f′=rmod2t on the limbs, rather than as a whole. As described above, each foreign field element xxx is split into three 88-bit limbs: x0,x1,x2x_0, x_1, x_2x0​,x1​,x2​, where x0x_0x0​ contains the least significant bits and x2x_2x2​ contains the most significant bits and so on.

Expanding the right-hand side into limbs we have

(a0+a1⋅2ℓ+a2⋅22ℓ)⋅(b0+b1⋅2ℓ+b2⋅22ℓ)+(q0+q1⋅2ℓ+q2⋅22ℓ)⋅(f0′+f1′⋅2ℓ+f2′⋅22ℓ)=     a0⋅b0+a0⋅b1⋅2ℓ+a0⋅b2⋅22ℓ    +a1⋅b0⋅2ℓ+a1⋅b1⋅22ℓ+a1⋅b2⋅23ℓ    +a2⋅b0⋅22ℓ+a2⋅b1⋅23ℓ+a2⋅b2⋅24ℓ+     q0⋅f0′+q0⋅f1′⋅2ℓ+q0⋅f2′⋅22ℓ    +q1⋅f0′⋅2ℓ+q1⋅f1′⋅22ℓ+q1⋅f2′⋅23ℓ    +q2⋅f0′⋅22ℓ+q2⋅f1′⋅23ℓ+q2⋅f2′⋅24ℓ=a0⋅b0+q0⋅f0′+2ℓ⋅(a0⋅b1+a1⋅b0+q0⋅f1′+q1⋅f0′)+22ℓ⋅(a0⋅b2+a2⋅b0+q0⋅f2′+q2⋅f0′+a1⋅b1+q1⋅f1′)+23ℓ⋅(a1⋅b2+a2⋅b1+q1⋅f2′+q2⋅f1′)+24ℓ⋅(a2⋅b2+q2⋅f2′)\begin{aligned} &(a_0 + a_1 \cdot 2^{\ell} + a_2 \cdot 2^{2\ell}) \cdot (b_0 + b_1 \cdot 2^{\ell} + b_2 \cdot 2^{2\ell}) + (q_0 + q_1 \cdot 2^{\ell} + q_2 \cdot 2^{2\ell}) \cdot (f'_0 + f'_1 \cdot 2^{\ell} + f'_2 \cdot 2^{2\ell}) \\ &=\\ &~~~~~ a_0 \cdot b_0 + a_0 \cdot b_1 \cdot 2^{\ell} + a_0 \cdot b_2 \cdot 2^{2\ell} \\ &~~~~ + a_1 \cdot b_0 \cdot 2^{\ell} + a_1 \cdot b_1 \cdot 2^{2\ell} + a_1 \cdot b_2 \cdot 2^{3\ell} \\ &~~~~ + a_2 \cdot b_0 \cdot 2^{2\ell} + a_2 \cdot b_1 \cdot 2^{3\ell} + a_2 \cdot b_2 \cdot 2^{4\ell} \\ &+ \\ &~~~~~ q_0 \cdot f'_0 + q_0 \cdot f'_1 \cdot 2^{\ell} + q_0 \cdot f'_2 \cdot 2^{2\ell} \\ &~~~~ + q_1 \cdot f'_0 \cdot 2^{\ell} + q_1 \cdot f'_1 \cdot 2^{2\ell} + q_1 \cdot f'_2 \cdot 2^{3\ell} \\ &~~~~ + q_2 \cdot f'_0 \cdot 2^{2\ell} + q_2 \cdot f'_1 \cdot 2^{3\ell} + q_2 \cdot f'_2 \cdot 2^{4\ell} \\ &= \\ &a_0 \cdot b_0 + q_0 \cdot f'_0 \\ &+ 2^{\ell} \cdot (a_0 \cdot b_1 + a_1 \cdot b_0 + q_0 \cdot f'_1 + q_1 \cdot f'_0) \\ &+ 2^{2\ell} \cdot (a_0 \cdot b_2 + a_2 \cdot b_0 + q_0 \cdot f'_2 + q_2 \cdot f'_0 + a_1 \cdot b_1 + q_1 \cdot f'_1) \\ &+ 2^{3\ell} \cdot (a_1 \cdot b_2 + a_2 \cdot b_1 + q_1 \cdot f'_2 + q_2 \cdot f'_1) \\ &+ 2^{4\ell} \cdot (a_2 \cdot b_2 + q_2 \cdot f'_2) \\ \end{aligned}​(a0​+a1​⋅2ℓ+a2​⋅22ℓ)⋅(b0​+b1​⋅2ℓ+b2​⋅22ℓ)+(q0​+q1​⋅2ℓ+q2​⋅22ℓ)⋅(f0′​+f1′​⋅2ℓ+f2′​⋅22ℓ)=     a0​⋅b0​+a0​⋅b1​⋅2ℓ+a0​⋅b2​⋅22ℓ    +a1​⋅b0​⋅2ℓ+a1​⋅b1​⋅22ℓ+a1​⋅b2​⋅23ℓ    +a2​⋅b0​⋅22ℓ+a2​⋅b1​⋅23ℓ+a2​⋅b2​⋅24ℓ+     q0​⋅f0′​+q0​⋅f1′​⋅2ℓ+q0​⋅f2′​⋅22ℓ    +q1​⋅f0′​⋅2ℓ+q1​⋅f1′​⋅22ℓ+q1​⋅f2′​⋅23ℓ    +q2​⋅f0′​⋅22ℓ+q2​⋅f1′​⋅23ℓ+q2​⋅f2′​⋅24ℓ=a0​⋅b0​+q0​⋅f0′​+2ℓ⋅(a0​⋅b1​+a1​⋅b0​+q0​⋅f1′​+q1​⋅f0′​)+22ℓ⋅(a0​⋅b2​+a2​⋅b0​+q0​⋅f2′​+q2​⋅f0′​+a1​⋅b1​+q1​⋅f1′​)+23ℓ⋅(a1​⋅b2​+a2​⋅b1​+q1​⋅f2′​+q2​⋅f1′​)+24ℓ⋅(a2​⋅b2​+q2​⋅f2′​)​

Since t=3ℓt = 3\ellt=3ℓ, the terms scaled by 23ℓ2^{3\ell}23ℓ and 24ℓ2^{4\ell}24ℓ are a multiple of the binary modulus and, thus, congruent to zero mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t. They can be eliminated and we don't need to compute them. So we are left with 3 intermediate products that we call p0,p1,p2p_0, p_1, p_2p0​,p1​,p2​:

So far, we have introduced these checked computations to our constraints

  1. Computation of p0,p1,p2p_0, p_1, p_2p0​,p1​,p2​

Constraining mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t​

Let's call p:=ab+qf′mod  2tp := ab + qf' \mod 2^tp:=ab+qf′mod2t. Remember that our goal is to constrain that p−r=0mod  2tp - r = 0 \mod 2^tp−r=0mod2t (recall that any more significant bits than the 264th are ignored in mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t). Decomposing that claim into limbs, that means

22ℓ(p2−r2)+2ℓ(p1−r1)+p0−r0=0mod  2t.\begin{aligned} 2^{2\ell}(p_2 - r_2) + 2^{\ell}(p_1 - r_1) + p_0 - r_0 = 0 \mod 2^t. \end{aligned}22ℓ(p2​−r2​)+2ℓ(p1​−r1​)+p0​−r0​=0mod2t.​

We face two challenges

  • Since p0,p1,p2p_0, p_1, p_2p0​,p1​,p2​ are at least 2ℓ2^{\ell}2ℓ bits each, the right side of the equation above does not fit in Fn\mathbb{F}_nFn​
  • The subtraction of the remainder's limbs r0r_0r0​ and r1r_1r1​ could require borrowing

For the moment, let's not worry about the possibility of borrows and instead focus on the first problem.

Combining multiplications​

The first problem is that our native field is too small to constrain 22ℓ(p2−r2)+2ℓ(p1−r1)+p0−r0=0mod  2t2^{2\ell}(p_2 - r_2) + 2^{\ell}(p_1 - r_1) + p_0 - r_0 = 0 \mod 2^t22ℓ(p2​−r2​)+2ℓ(p1​−r1​)+p0​−r0​=0mod2t. We could split this up by multiplying a⋅ba \cdot ba⋅b and q⋅f′q \cdot f'q⋅f′ separately and create constraints that carefully track borrows and carries between limbs. However, a more efficient approach is combined the whole computation together and accumulate all the carries and borrows in order to reduce their number.

The trick is to assume a space large enough to hold the computation, view the outcome in binary and then split it up into chunks that fit in the native modulus.

To this end, it helps to know how many bits these intermediate products require. On the left side of the equation, p0p_0p0​ is at most 2ℓ+12\ell + 12ℓ+1 bits. We can compute this by substituting the maximum possible binary values (all bits set to 1) into p0=a0b0+q0f0′p_0 = a_0b_0 + q_0f'_0p0​=a0​b0​+q0​f0′​ like this

maxbits(p0)=log⁡2((2ℓ−1)⏟a0(2ℓ−1)⏟b0+(2ℓ−1)⏟q0(2ℓ−1)⏟f0′)=log⁡2(2(22ℓ−2ℓ+1+1))=log⁡2(22ℓ+1−2ℓ+2+2).\begin{aligned} \mathsf{maxbits}(p_0) &= \log_2(\underbrace{(2^{\ell} - 1)}_{a_{0}} \underbrace{(2^{\ell} - 1)}_{b_{0}} + \underbrace{(2^{\ell} - 1)}_{q_{0}} \underbrace{(2^{\ell} - 1)}_{f'_{0}}) \\ &= \log_2(2(2^{2\ell} - 2^{\ell + 1} + 1)) \\ &= \log_2(2^{2\ell + 1} - 2^{\ell + 2} + 2). \end{aligned}maxbits(p0​)​=log2​(a0​(2ℓ−1)​​b0​(2ℓ−1)​​+q0​(2ℓ−1)​​f0′​(2ℓ−1)​​)=log2​(2(22ℓ−2ℓ+1+1))=log2​(22ℓ+1−2ℓ+2+2).​

So p0p_0p0​ fits in 2ℓ+12\ell + 12ℓ+1 bits. Similarly, p1p_1p1​ needs at most 2ℓ+22\ell + 22ℓ+2 bits and p2p_2p2​ is at most 2ℓ+32\ell + 32ℓ+3 bits.

Termp0p_0p0​p1p_1p1​p2p_2p2​
Bits2ℓ+12\ell + 12ℓ+12ℓ+22\ell + 22ℓ+22ℓ+32\ell + 32ℓ+3

The diagram below shows the right hand side of the zero-sum equality from equation (2). That is, the value p−rp - rp−r. Let's look at how the different bits of p0,p1,p2,r0,r1p_0, p_1, p_2, r_0, r_1p0​,p1​,p2​,r0​,r1​ and r2r_2r2​ impact it.

0             L             2L            3L            4L
|-------------|-------------|-------------|-------------|-------------|
                            :
|--------------p0-----------:-| 2L + 1
                            :
              |-------------:-p1------------| 2L + 2
                    p10➚    :        p11➚
                            |----------------p2-------------| 2L + 3
                            :
|-----r0------|             :
                            :
              |-----r1------|
                            :
                            |-----r2------|
\__________________________/ \______________________________/
             ≈ h0                           ≈ h1

Within our native field modulus we can fit up to 2ℓ+δ<log⁡2(n)2\ell + \delta < \log_2(n)2ℓ+δ<log2​(n) bits, for small values of δ\deltaδ (but sufficient for our case). Thus, we can only constrain approximately half of p−rp - rp−r at a time. In the diagram above the vertical line at 2L bisects p−rp - rp−r into two ≈2ℓ\approx2\ell≈2ℓ bit values: h0h_0h0​ and h1h_1h1​ (the exact definition of these values follow). Our goal is to constrain h0h_0h0​ and h1h_1h1​.

Computing the zero-sum halves: h0h_0h0​ and h1h_1h1​​

Now we can derive how to compute h0h_0h0​ and h1h_1h1​ from ppp and rrr.

The direct approach would be to bisect both p0p_0p0​ and p1p_1p1​ and then define h0h_0h0​ as just the sum of the 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ lower bits of p0p_0p0​ and p1p_1p1​ minus r0r_0r0​ and r1r_1r1​. Similarly h1h_1h1​ would be just the sum of upper bits of p0,p1p_0, p_1p0​,p1​ and p2p_2p2​ minus r2r_2r2​. However, each bisection requires constraints for the decomposition and range checks for the two halves. Thus, we would like to avoid bisections as they are expensive.

Ideally, if our ppp's lined up on the 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ boundary, we would not need to bisect at all. However, we are unlucky and it seems like we must bisect both p0p_0p0​ and p1p_1p1​. Fortunately, we can at least avoid bisecting p0p_0p0​ by allowing it to be summed into h0h_0h0​ like this

h0=p0+2ℓ⋅p10−r0−2ℓ⋅r1h_0 = p_0 + 2^{\ell}\cdot p_{10} - r_0 - 2^{\ell}\cdot r_1h0​=p0​+2ℓ⋅p10​−r0​−2ℓ⋅r1​

Note that h0h_0h0​ is actually greater than 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ bits in length. This may not only be because it contains p0p_0p0​ whose length is 2ℓ+12\ell + 12ℓ+1, but also because adding p10p_{10}p10​ may cause an overflow. The maximum length of h0h_0h0​ is computed by substituting in the maximum possible binary value of 2ℓ−12^{\ell} - 12ℓ−1 for the added terms and 000 for the subtracted terms of the above equation.

maxbits(h0)=log⁡2((2ℓ−1)(2ℓ−1)+(2ℓ−1)(2ℓ−1)⏟p0+2ℓ⋅(2ℓ−1)⏟p10)=log⁡2(22ℓ+1−2ℓ+2+2+22ℓ−2ℓ)=log⁡2(3⋅22ℓ−5⋅2ℓ+2)\begin{aligned} \mathsf{maxbits}(h_0) &= \log_2(\underbrace{(2^{\ell} - 1)(2^{\ell} - 1) + (2^{\ell} - 1)(2^{\ell} - 1)}_{p_0} + 2^{\ell} \cdot \underbrace{(2^{\ell} - 1)}_{p_{10}}) \\ &= \log_2(2^{2\ell + 1} - 2^{\ell + 2} + 2 + 2^{2\ell} - 2^\ell) \\ &= \log_2( 3\cdot 2^{2\ell} - 5 \cdot 2^\ell +2 ) \\ \end{aligned}maxbits(h0​)​=log2​(p0​(2ℓ−1)(2ℓ−1)+(2ℓ−1)(2ℓ−1)​​+2ℓ⋅p10​(2ℓ−1)​​)=log2​(22ℓ+1−2ℓ+2+2+22ℓ−2ℓ)=log2​(3⋅22ℓ−5⋅2ℓ+2)​

which is 2ℓ+22\ell + 22ℓ+2 bits.

N.b. This computation assumes correct sizes values for r0r_0r0​ and r1r_1r1​, which we assure by range checks on the limbs.

Next, we compute h1h_1h1​ as

h1=p11+p2−r2h_1 = p_{11} + p_2 - r_2h1​=p11​+p2​−r2​

The maximum size of h1h_1h1​ is computed as

maxbits(h1)=maxbits(p11+p2)\begin{aligned} \mathsf{maxbits}(h_1) &= \mathsf{maxbits}(p_{11} + p_2) \end{aligned}maxbits(h1​)​=maxbits(p11​+p2​)​

In order to obtain the maximum value of p11p_{11}p11​, we define p11:=p12ℓp_{11} := \frac{p_1}{2^\ell}p11​:=2ℓp1​​. Since the maximum value of p1p_1p1​ was 22ℓ+2−2ℓ+3+42^{2\ell+2}-2^{\ell+3}+422ℓ+2−2ℓ+3+4, then the maximum value of p11p_{11}p11​ is 2ℓ+2−82^{\ell+2}-82ℓ+2−8. For p2p_2p2​, the maximum value was 6⋅22ℓ−12⋅2ℓ+66\cdot 2^{2\ell} - 12 \cdot 2^\ell + 66⋅22ℓ−12⋅2ℓ+6, and thus:

maxbits(h1)=log2(2ℓ+2−8⏟p11+6⋅22ℓ−12⋅2ℓ+6⏟p2)=log⁡2(6⋅22ℓ−8⋅2ℓ−2)\begin{aligned} \mathsf{maxbits}(h_1) &= log_2(\underbrace{2^{\ell+2}-8}_{p_{11}} + \underbrace{6\cdot 2^{2\ell} - 12 \cdot 2^\ell + 6}_{p_2}) \\ &= \log_2(6\cdot 2^{2\ell} - 8 \cdot 2^\ell - 2) \\ \end{aligned}maxbits(h1​)​=log2​(p11​2ℓ+2−8​​+p2​6⋅22ℓ−12⋅2ℓ+6​​)=log2​(6⋅22ℓ−8⋅2ℓ−2)​

which is 2ℓ+32\ell + 32ℓ+3 bits.

Termh0h_0h0​h1h_1h1​
Bits2ℓ+22\ell + 22ℓ+22ℓ+32\ell + 32ℓ+3

Thus far we have the following constraints

  1. Composition of p10p_{10}p10​ and p11p_{11}p11​ result in p1p_1p1​
  2. Range check p11∈[0,2ℓ+2)p_{11} \in [0, 2^{\ell + 2})p11​∈[0,2ℓ+2)
  3. Range check p10∈[0,2ℓ)p_{10} \in [0, 2^{\ell})p10​∈[0,2ℓ)

For the next step we would like to constrain h0h_0h0​ and h1h_1h1​ to zero. Unfortunately, we are not able to do this!

  • Firstly, as defined h0h_0h0​ may not be zero because we have not bisected it precisely at 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ bits, but have allowed it to contain the full 2ℓ+22\ell + 22ℓ+2 bits. Recall that these two additional bits are because p0p_0p0​ is at most 2ℓ+12\ell + 12ℓ+1 bits long, but also because adding p10p_{10}p10​ increases it to 2ℓ+22\ell + 22ℓ+2. These two additional bits are not part of the first 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ bits of p−rp - rp−r and, thus, are not necessarily zero. That is, they are added from the second 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ bits (i.e. h1h_1h1​).

  • Secondly, whilst the highest ℓ+3\ell + 3ℓ+3 bits of p−rp - rp−r would wrap to zero mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t, when placed into the smaller 2ℓ+32\ell + 32ℓ+3 bit h1h_1h1​ in the native field, this wrapping does not happen. Thus, h1h_1h1​'s ℓ+3\ell + 3ℓ+3 highest bits may be nonzero.

We can deal with this non-zero issue by computing carry witness values.

Computing carry witnesses values v0v_0v0​ and v1v_1v1​​

Instead of constraining h0h_0h0​ and h1h_1h1​ to zero, there must be satisfying witness v0v_0v0​ and v1v_1v1​ such that the following constraints hold.

  1. There exists v0v_0v0​ such that h0=v0⋅22ℓh_0 = v_0 \cdot 2^{2\ell}h0​=v0​⋅22ℓ
  2. There exists v1v_1v1​ such that h1=v1⋅2ℓ−v0h_1 = v_1 \cdot 2^{\ell} - v_0h1​=v1​⋅2ℓ−v0​

Here v0v_0v0​ is the last two bits of h0h_0h0​'s 2ℓ+22\ell + 22ℓ+2 bits, i.e., the result of adding the highest bit of p0p_0p0​ and any possible carry bit from the operation of h0h_0h0​. Similarly, v1v_1v1​ corresponds to the highest ℓ+3\ell + 3ℓ+3 bits of h1h_1h1​. It looks like this

0             L             2L            3L            4L
|-------------|-------------|-------------|-------------|-------------|
                            :
|--------------h0-----------:--| 2L + 2
                            : ↖v0
                            :-------------h1-------------| 2L + 3
                            :              \____________/
                            :                  v1➚

Remember we only need to prove the first 3ℓ3\ell3ℓ bits of p−rp - rp−r are zero, since everything is mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t and t=3ℓt = 3\ellt=3ℓ. It may not be clear how this approach proves the 3ℓ3\ell3ℓ bits are indeed zero because within h0h_0h0​ and h1h_1h1​ there are bits that are nonzero. The key observation is that these bits are too high for mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t.

By making the argument with v0v_0v0​ and v1v_1v1​ we are proving that h0h_0h0​ is something where the 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ least significant bits are all zeros and that h1+v0h_1 + v_0h1​+v0​ is something where the ℓ\ellℓ are also zeros. Any nonzero bits after 3ℓ3\ell3ℓ do not matter, since everything is mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t.

All that remains is to range check v0v_0v0​ and v1v_1v1​

  1. Range check v0∈[0,22)v_0 \in [0, 2^2)v0​∈[0,22)
  2. Range check v1=∈[0,2ℓ+3)v_1 =\in [0, 2^{\ell + 3})v1​=∈[0,2ℓ+3)

Subtractions​

When unconstrained, computing u0=p0+2ℓ⋅p10−(r0+2ℓ⋅r1)u_0 = p_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot p_{10} - (r_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot r_1)u0​=p0​+2ℓ⋅p10​−(r0​+2ℓ⋅r1​) could require borrowing. Fortunately, we have the constraint that the 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ least significant bits of u0u_0u0​ are 0 (i.e. u0=22ℓ⋅v0u_0 = 2^{2\ell} \cdot v_0u0​=22ℓ⋅v0​), which means borrowing cannot happen.

Borrowing is prevented because when the 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ least significant bits of the result are 0 it is not possible for the minuend to be less than the subtrahend. We can prove this by contradiction.

Let

  • x=p0+2ℓ⋅p10x = p_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot p_{10}x=p0​+2ℓ⋅p10​
  • y=r0+2ℓ⋅r1y = r_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot r_1y=r0​+2ℓ⋅r1​
  • the 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ least significant bits of x−yx - yx−y be 0

Suppose that borrowing occurs, that is, that x<yx < yx<y. Recall that the length of xxx is at most 2ℓ+22\ell + 22ℓ+2 bits. Therefore, since x<yx < yx<y the top two bits of xxx must be zero and so we have

x−y=x2ℓ−y,x - y = x_{2\ell} - y,x−y=x2ℓ​−y,

where x2ℓx_{2\ell}x2ℓ​ denotes the 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ least significant bits of xxx.

Recall also that the length of yyy is 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ bits. We know this because limbs of the result are each constrained to be in [0,2ℓ)[0, 2^{\ell})[0,2ℓ). So the result of this subtraction is 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ bits. Since the 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ least significant bits of the subtraction are 0 this means that

x−y=0x=y,\begin{aligned} x - y & = 0 \\ x &= y, \end{aligned}x−yx​=0=y,​

which is a contradiction with x<yx < yx<y.

Costs​

Range checks should be the dominant cost, let's see how many we have.

Range check (3) requires two range checks for p11=p111⋅2ℓ+p110p_{11} = p_{111} \cdot 2^\ell + p_{110}p11​=p111​⋅2ℓ+p110​

  • a) p110∈[0,2ℓ)p_{110} \in [0, 2^\ell)p110​∈[0,2ℓ)
  • b) p111∈[0,22)p_{111} \in [0, 2^2)p111​∈[0,22)

Range check (8) requires two range checks and a decomposition check that is merged in (6).

  • a) v10∈[0,2ℓ)v_{10} \in [0, 2^{\ell})v10​∈[0,2ℓ)
  • b) v11∈[0,23)v_{11} \in [0, 2^3)v11​∈[0,23)

The range checks on p0,p1p_0, p_1p0​,p1​ and p2p_2p2​ follow from the range checks on a,ba,ba,b and qqq.

So we have 3.a, 3.b, 4, 7, 8.a, 8.b.

Range checkGate type(s)WitnessRows
7(v0−3)(v0−2)(v0−1)v0(v_0 - 3)(v_0 - 2)(v_0 - 1)v_0(v0​−3)(v0​−2)(v0​−1)v0​v0v_0v0​< 1
3.a(p111−3)(p111−2)(p111−1)p111(p_{111} - 3)(p_{111} - 2)(p_{111} - 1)p_{111}(p111​−3)(p111​−2)(p111​−1)p111​p111p_{111}p111​< 1

So we have 1 multi-range-check, 1 single-range-check and 2 low-degree range checks. This consumes just over 5 rows.

Use CRT to constrain a⋅b−q⋅f−r≡0mod  na \cdot b - q \cdot f - r \equiv 0 \mod na⋅b−q⋅f−r≡0modn​

Until now we have constrained the equation mod  2t\mod 2^tmod2t, but remember that our application of the CRT means that we must also constrain the equation mod  n\mod nmodn. We are leveraging the fact that if the identity holds for all moduli in M={n,2t}\mathcal{M} = \{n, 2^t\}M={n,2t}, then it holds for lcm(M)=2t⋅n=M\mathtt{lcm} (\mathcal{M}) = 2^t \cdot n = Mlcm(M)=2t⋅n=M.

Thus, we must check a⋅b−q⋅f−r≡0mod  na \cdot b - q \cdot f - r \equiv 0 \mod na⋅b−q⋅f−r≡0modn, which is over Fn\mathbb{F}_nFn​.

This gives us equality mod  2t⋅n\mod 2^t \cdot nmod2t⋅n as long as the divisors are coprime. That is, as long as gcd(2t,n)=1\mathsf{gcd}(2^t, n) = 1gcd(2t,n)=1. Since the native modulus nnn is prime, this is true.

Thus, to perform this check is simple. We compute

an=amod  nbn=bmod  nqn=qmod  nrn=rmod  nfn=fmod  n\begin{aligned} a_n &= a \mod n \\ b_n &= b \mod n \\ q_n &= q \mod n \\ r_n &= r \mod n \\ f_n &= f \mod n \end{aligned}an​bn​qn​rn​fn​​=amodn=bmodn=qmodn=rmodn=fmodn​

using our native field modulus with constraints like this

an=22ℓ⋅a2+2ℓ⋅a1+a0bn=22ℓ⋅b2+2ℓ⋅b1+b0qn=22ℓ⋅q2+2ℓ⋅q1+q0rn=22ℓ⋅r2+2ℓ⋅r1+r0fn=22ℓ⋅f2+2ℓ⋅f1+f0\begin{aligned} a_n &= 2^{2\ell} \cdot a_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot a_1 + a_0 \\ b_n &= 2^{2\ell} \cdot b_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot b_1 + b_0 \\ q_n &= 2^{2\ell} \cdot q_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q_1 + q_0 \\ r_n & = 2^{2\ell} \cdot r_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot r_1 + r_0 \\ f_n &= 2^{2\ell} \cdot f_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot f_1 + f_0 \\ \end{aligned}an​bn​qn​rn​fn​​=22ℓ⋅a2​+2ℓ⋅a1​+a0​=22ℓ⋅b2​+2ℓ⋅b1​+b0​=22ℓ⋅q2​+2ℓ⋅q1​+q0​=22ℓ⋅r2​+2ℓ⋅r1​+r0​=22ℓ⋅f2​+2ℓ⋅f1​+f0​​

and then constrain

an⋅bn−qn⋅fn−rn=0mod  n.a_n \cdot b_n - q_n \cdot f_n - r_n = 0 \mod n.an​⋅bn​−qn​⋅fn​−rn​=0modn.

Note that we do not use the negated foreign field modulus here.

This requires a single constraint of the form

  1. an⋅bn−qn⋅fn=rna_n \cdot b_n - q_n \cdot f_n = r_nan​⋅bn​−qn​⋅fn​=rn​

with all of the terms expanded into the limbs according the above equations. The values an,bn,qn,fna_n, b_n, q_n, f_nan​,bn​,qn​,fn​ and rnr_nrn​ do not need to be in the witness.

Range check both sides of a⋅b=q⋅f+ra \cdot b = q \cdot f + ra⋅b=q⋅f+r​

Until now we have constrained that equation a⋅b=q⋅f+ra \cdot b = q \cdot f + ra⋅b=q⋅f+r holds modulo 2t2^t2t and modulo nnn, so by the CRT it holds modulo M=2t⋅nM = 2^t \cdot nM=2t⋅n. Remember that, as outlined in the "Overview" section, we must prove our equation over the positive integers, rather than mod  M\mod MmodM. By doing so, we assure that our solution is not equal to some q′⋅M+r′q' \cdot M + r'q′⋅M+r′ where q′,r′∈FMq', r' \in F_{M}q′,r′∈FM​, in which case qqq or rrr would be invalid.

First, let's consider the right hand side q⋅f+rq \cdot f + rq⋅f+r. We have

q⋅f+r<2t⋅nq \cdot f + r < 2^t \cdot nq⋅f+r<2t⋅n

Recall that we have parameterized 2t⋅n≥f22^t \cdot n \ge f^22t⋅n≥f2, so if we can bound qqq and rrr such that

q⋅f+r<f2q \cdot f + r < f^2q⋅f+r<f2

then we have achieved our goal. We know that qqq must be less than fff, so that is our first check, leaving us with

(f−1)⋅f+r<f2r<f2−(f−1)⋅f=f\begin{aligned} (f - 1) \cdot f + r &< f^2 \\ r &< f^2 - (f - 1) \cdot f = f \end{aligned}(f−1)⋅f+rr​<f2<f2−(f−1)⋅f=f​

Therefore, to check q⋅f+r<2t⋅nq \cdot f + r < 2^t \cdot nq⋅f+r<2t⋅n, we need to check

  • q<fq < fq<f
  • r<fr < fr<f

This should come at no surprise, since that is how we parameterized 2t⋅n2^t \cdot n2t⋅n earlier on. Note that by checking q<fq < fq<f we assure correctness, while checking r<fr < fr<f assures our solution is unique (sometimes referred to as canonical).

Next, we must perform the same checks for the left hand side (i.e., a⋅b<2t⋅na \cdot b < 2^t \cdot na⋅b<2t⋅n). Since aaa and bbb must be less than the foreign field modulus fff, this means checking

  • a<fa < fa<f
  • b<fb < fb<f

So we have

a⋅b≤(f−1)⋅(f−1)=f2−2f+1\begin{aligned} a \cdot b &\le (f - 1) \cdot (f - 1) = f^2 - 2f + 1 \\ \end{aligned}a⋅b​≤(f−1)⋅(f−1)=f2−2f+1​

Since 2t⋅n≥f22^t \cdot n \ge f^22t⋅n≥f2 we have

f2−2f+1<f2≤2t⋅n  ⟹  a⋅b<2t⋅n\begin{aligned} &f^2 - 2f + 1 < f^2 \le 2^t \cdot n \\ &\implies a \cdot b < 2^t \cdot n \end{aligned}​f2−2f+1<f2≤2t⋅n⟹a⋅b<2t⋅n​

Bound checks​

To perform the above range checks we use the upper bound check method described in the upper bound check section in Foreign Field Addition.

The upper bound check is as follows. We must constrain 0≤q<f0 \le q < f0≤q<f over the positive integers, so

2t≤q+2t<f+2t2t−f≤q+2t−f<2t\begin{aligned} 2^t \le q &+ 2^t < f + 2^t \\ 2^t - f \le q &+ 2^t - f < 2^t \\ \end{aligned}2t≤q2t−f≤q​+2t<f+2t+2t−f<2t​

Remember f′=2t−ff' = 2^t - ff′=2t−f is our negated foreign field modulus. Thus, we have

f′≤q+f′<2t\begin{aligned} f' \le q &+ f' < 2^t \\ \end{aligned}f′≤q​+f′<2t​

So to check q<tq < tq<t we just need to compute q′=q+f′q' = q + f'q′=q+f′ and check f′≤q′<2tf' \le q' < 2^tf′≤q′<2t

Observe that

0≤q  ⟹  f′≤q′0 \le q \implies f' \le q'0≤q⟹f′≤q′

and that

q′<2t  ⟹  q<fq' < 2^t \implies q < fq′<2t⟹q<f

So we only need to check

  • 0≤q0 \le q0≤q
  • q′<2tq' < 2^tq′<2t

The first check is always true since we are operating over the positive integers and q∈Z+q \in \mathbb{Z^+}q∈Z+. Observe that the second check also constrains that q<2tq < 2^tq<2t, since f≤2259<2tf \le 2^{259} < 2^tf≤2259<2t and thus

q′≤2tq+f′≤2tq≤2t−(2t−f)=fq<2t\begin{aligned} q' &\le 2^t \\ q + f' &\le 2^t \\ q &\le 2^t - (2^t - f) = f\\ q &< 2^t \end{aligned}q′q+f′qq​≤2t≤2t≤2t−(2t−f)=f<2t​

Therefore, to constrain q<fq < fq<f we only need constraints for

  • q′=q+f′q' = q + f'q′=q+f′
  • q′<2tq' < 2^tq′<2t

and we don't require an additional multi-range-check for q<2tq < 2^tq<2t.

Cost of bound checks​

This section analyzes the structure and costs of bounds checks for foreign field addition and foreign field multiplication.

Addition​

In our foreign field addition design the operands aaa and bbb do not need to be less than fff. The field overflow bit o\mathcal{o}o for foreign field addition is at most 1. That is, a+b=o⋅f+ra + b = \mathcal{o} \cdot f + ra+b=o⋅f+r, where rrr is allowed to be greater than fff. Therefore,

(f+a)+(f+b)=1⋅f+(f+a+b)(f + a) + (f + b) = 1 \cdot f + (f + a + b)(f+a)+(f+b)=1⋅f+(f+a+b)

These can be chained along kkk times as desired. The final result

r=(f+⋯+f⏟k+a1+b1+⋯ak+bk)r = (\underbrace{f + \cdots + f}_{k} + a_1 + b_1 + \cdots a_k + b_k)r=(kf+⋯+f​​+a1​+b1​+⋯ak​+bk​)

Since the bit length of rrr increases logarithmically with the number of additions, in Kimchi we must only check that the final rrr in the chain is less than fff to constrain the entire chain.

Security note: In order to defer the r<fr < fr<f check to the end of any chain of additions, it is extremely important to consider the potential impact of wraparound in Fn\mathbb{F_n}Fn​. That is, we need to consider whether the addition of a large chain of elements greater than the foreign field modulus could wrap around. If this could happen then the r<fr < fr<f check could fail to detect an invalid witness. Below we will show that this is not possible in Kimchi.

Recall that our foreign field elements are comprised of 3 limbs of 88-bits each that are each represented as native field elements in our proof system. In order to wrap around and circumvent the r<fr < fr<f check, the highest limb would need to wrap around. This means that an attacker would need to perform about k≈n/2ℓk \approx n/2^{\ell}k≈n/2ℓ additions of elements greater than then foreign field modulus. Since Kimchi's native moduli (Pallas and Vesta) are 255-bits, the attacker would need to provide a witness for about k≈2167k \approx 2^{167}k≈2167 additions. This length of witness is greater than Kimchi's maximum circuit (resp. witness) length. Thus, it is not possible for the attacker to generate a false proof by causing wraparound with a large chain of additions.

In summary, for foreign field addition in Kimchi it is sufficient to only bound check the last result r′r'r′ in a chain of additions (and subtractions)

  • Compute bound r′=r+f′r' = r + f'r′=r+f′ with addition gate (2 rows)
  • Range check r′<2tr' < 2^tr′<2t (4 rows)

Multiplication​

In foreign field multiplication, the situation is unfortunately different, and we must check that each of a,b,qa, b, qa,b,q and rrr are less than fff. We cannot adopt the strategy from foreign field addition where the operands are allowed to be greater than fff because the bit length of rrr would increases linearly with the number of multiplications. That is,

(a1+f)⋅(a2+f)=1⋅f+f2+(a1+a2−1)⋅f+a1⋅a2⏟r(a_1 + f) \cdot (a_2 + f) = 1 \cdot f + \underbrace{f^2 + (a_1 + a_2 - 1) \cdot f + a_1 \cdot a_2}_{r}(a1​+f)⋅(a2​+f)=1⋅f+rf2+(a1​+a2​−1)⋅f+a1​⋅a2​​​

and after a chain of kkk multiplication we have

r=fk+…+a1⋯akr = f^k + \ldots + a_1 \cdots a_kr=fk+…+a1​⋯ak​

where r>fkr > f^kr>fk quickly overflows our CRT modulus 2t⋅n2^t \cdot n2t⋅n. For example, assuming our maximum foreign modulus of f=2259f = 2^{259}f=2259 and either of Kimchi's native moduli (i.e. Pallas or Vesta), fk>2t⋅nf^k > 2^t \cdot nfk>2t⋅n for k>2k > 2k>2. That is, an overflow is possible for a chain of greater than 1 foreign field multiplication. Thus, we must check a,b,qa, b, qa,b,q and rrr are less than fff for each multiplication.

Fortunately, in many situations the input operands may already be checked either as inputs or as outputs of previous operations, so they may not be required for each multiplication operation.

Thus, the q′q'q′ and r′r'r′ checks (or equivalently qqq and rrr) are our main focus because they must be done for every multiplication.

  • Compute bound q′=q+f′q' = q + f'q′=q+f′ with addition gate (2 rows)
  • Compute bound r′=r+f′r' = r + f'r′=r+f′ with addition gate (2 rows)
  • Range check q′<2tq' < 2^tq′<2t (4 rows)
  • Range check r′<2tr' < 2^tr′<2t (4 rows)

This costs 12 rows per multiplication. In a subsequent section, we will reduce it to 8 rows.

2-limb decomposition​

Due to the limited number of permutable cells per gate, we do not have enough cells for copy constraining q′q'q′ and r′r'r′ (or qqq and rrr) to their respective range check gadgets. To address this issue, we must decompose q′q'q′ into 2 limbs instead of 3, like so

q′=q01′+22ℓ⋅q2′q' = q'_{01} + 2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_2q′=q01′​+22ℓ⋅q2′​

and

q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​

Thus, q′q'q′ is decomposed into two limbs q01′q'_{01}q01′​ (at most 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ bits) and q2′q'_2q2′​ (at most ℓ\ellℓ bits).

Note that q′q'q′ must be range checked by a multi-range-check gadget. To do this the multi-range-check gadget must

  • Store a copy of the limbs q0′,q1′q'_0, q'_1q0′​,q1′​ and q2′q'_2q2′​ in its witness
  • Range check that they are ℓ\ellℓ bit each
  • Constrain that q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​ (this is done with a special mode of the multi-range-check gadget)
  • Have copy constraints for q01′q'_{01}q01′​ and q2′q'_2q2′​ as outputs of the ForeignFieldMul gate and inputs to the multi-range-check gadget

Note that since the foreign field multiplication gate computes q′q'q′ from qqq which is already in the witness and q01′q'_{01}q01′​ and q2′q'_2q2′​ have copy constraints to a multi-range-check gadget that fully constrains their decomposition from q′q'q′, then the ForeignFieldMul gate does not need to store an additional copy of q0′q'_0q0′​ and q1′q'_1q1′​.

An optimization​

Since the q<fq < fq<f and r<fr < fr<f checks must be done for each multiplication it makes sense to integrate them into the foreign field multiplication gate. By doing this we can save 4 rows per multiplication.

Doing this doesn't require adding a lot more witness data because the operands for the bound computations q′=q+f′q' = q + f'q′=q+f′ and r′=r+f′r' = r + f'r′=r+f′ are already present in the witness of the multiplication gate. We only need to store the bounds q′q'q′ and r′r'r′ in permutable witness cells so that they may be copied to multi-range-check gates to check they are each less than 2t2^t2t.

To constrain x+f′=x′x + f' = x'x+f′=x′, the equation we use is

x+2t=o⋅f+x′,x + 2^t = \mathcal{o} \cdot f + x',x+2t=o⋅f+x′,

where xxx is the original value, o=1\mathcal{o}=1o=1 is the field overflow bit and x′x'x′ is the remainder and our desired addition result (e.g. the bound). Rearranging things we get

x+2t−f=x′,x + 2^t - f = x',x+2t−f=x′,

which is just

x+f′=x′,x + f' = x',x+f′=x′,

Recall from the section "Avoiding borrows" that f′f'f′ is often larger than fff. At first this seems like it could be a problem because in multiplication each operation must be less than fff. However, this is because the maximum size of the multiplication was quadratic in the size of fff (we use the CRT, which requires the bound that a⋅b<2t⋅na \cdot b < 2^t \cdot na⋅b<2t⋅n). However, for addition the result is much smaller and we do not require the CRT nor the assumption that the operands are smaller than fff. Thus, we have plenty of space in ℓ\ellℓ-bit limbs to perform our addition.

So, the equation we need to constrain is

x+f′=x′.x + f' = x'.x+f′=x′.

We can expand the left hand side into the 2 limb format in order to obtain 2 intermediate sums

s01=x01+f01′s2=x2+f2′\begin{aligned} s_{01} = x_{01} + f_{01}' \\ s_2 = x_2 + f'_2 \\ \end{aligned}s01​=x01​+f01′​s2​=x2​+f2′​​

where x01x_{01}x01​ and f01′f'_{01}f01′​ are defined like this

x01=x0+2ℓ⋅x1f01′=f0′+2ℓ⋅f1′\begin{aligned} x_{01} = x_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot x_1 \\ f'_{01} = f'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot f'_1 \\ \end{aligned}x01​=x0​+2ℓ⋅x1​f01′​=f0′​+2ℓ⋅f1′​​

and xxx and f′f'f′ are defined like this

x=x01+22ℓ⋅x2f′=f01′+22ℓ⋅f2′\begin{aligned} x = x_{01} + 2^{2\ell} \cdot x_2 \\ f' = f'_{01} + 2^{2\ell} \cdot f'_2 \\ \end{aligned}x=x01​+22ℓ⋅x2​f′=f01′​+22ℓ⋅f2′​​

Going back to our intermediate sums, the maximum bit length of sum s01s_{01}s01​ is computed from the maximum bit lengths of x01x_{01}x01​ and f01′f'_{01}f01′​

(2ℓ−1)+2ℓ⋅(2ℓ−1)⏟x01+(2ℓ−1)+2ℓ⋅(2ℓ−1)⏟f01′=22ℓ+1−2,\underbrace{(2^{\ell} - 1) + 2^{\ell} \cdot (2^{\ell} - 1)}_{x_{01}} + \underbrace{(2^{\ell} - 1) + 2^{\ell} \cdot (2^{\ell} - 1)}_{f'_{01}} = 2^{2\ell+ 1} - 2,x01​(2ℓ−1)+2ℓ⋅(2ℓ−1)​​+f01′​(2ℓ−1)+2ℓ⋅(2ℓ−1)​​=22ℓ+1−2,

which means s01s_{01}s01​ is at most 2ℓ+12\ell + 12ℓ+1 bits long.

Similarly, since x2x_2x2​ and f2′f'_2f2′​ are less than 2ℓ2^{\ell}2ℓ, the max value of s2s_2s2​ is

(2ℓ−1)+(2ℓ−1)=2ℓ+1−2,(2^{\ell} - 1) + (2^{\ell} - 1) = 2^{\ell + 1} - 2,(2ℓ−1)+(2ℓ−1)=2ℓ+1−2,

which means s2s_2s2​ is at most ℓ+1\ell + 1ℓ+1 bits long.

Thus, we must constrain

s01+22ℓ⋅s2−x01′−22ℓ⋅x2′=0mod  2t.s_{01} + 2^{2\ell} \cdot s_2 - x'_{01} - 2^{2\ell} \cdot x'_2 = 0 \mod 2^t.s01​+22ℓ⋅s2​−x01′​−22ℓ⋅x2′​=0mod2t.

The accumulation of this into parts looks like this.

0             L             2L            3L=t          4L
|-------------|-------------|-------------|-------------|-------------|
                            :
|------------s01------------:-| 2L + 1
                            : ↖w01
                            |------s2-----:-| L + 1
                            :               ↖w2
                            :
|------------x'01-----------|
                            :
                            |------x'2----|
                            :
\____________________________/
             ≈ z01           \_____________/
                                   ≈ z2

The two parts are computed with

z01=s01−x01′z2=s2−x2′.\begin{aligned} z_{01} &= s_{01} - x'_{01} \\ z_2 &= s_2 - x'_2. \end{aligned}z01​z2​​=s01​−x01′​=s2​−x2′​.​

Therefore, there are two carry bits w01w_{01}w01​ and w2w_2w2​ such that

z01=22ℓ⋅w01z2+w01=2ℓ⋅w2\begin{aligned} z_{01} &= 2^{2\ell} \cdot w_{01} \\ z_2 + w_{01} &= 2^{\ell} \cdot w_2 \end{aligned}z01​z2​+w01​​=22ℓ⋅w01​=2ℓ⋅w2​​

In this scheme x01′,x2′,w01x'_{01}, x'_2, w_{01}x01′​,x2′​,w01​ and w2w_2w2​ are witness data, whereas s01s_{01}s01​ and s2s_2s2​ are formed from a constrained computation of witness data x01,x2x_{01}, x_2x01​,x2​ and constraint system public parameter f′f'f′. Note that due to carrying, witness x01′x'_{01}x01′​ and x2′x'_2x2′​ can be different than the values s01s_{01}s01​ and s2s_2s2​ computed from the limbs.

Thus, each bound addition x+f′x + f'x+f′ requires the following witness data

  • x01,x2x_{01}, x_2x01​,x2​
  • x01′,x2′x'_{01}, x'_2x01′​,x2′​
  • w01,w2w_{01}, w_2w01​,w2​

where f′f'f′ is baked into the gate coefficients. The following constraints are needed

  • 22ℓ⋅w01=s01−x01′2^{2\ell} \cdot w_{01} = s_{01} - x'_{01}22ℓ⋅w01​=s01​−x01′​
  • 2ℓ⋅w2=s2+w01−x2′2^{\ell} \cdot w_2 = s_2 + w_{01} - x'_22ℓ⋅w2​=s2​+w01​−x2′​
  • x01′∈[0,22ℓ)x'_{01} \in [0, 2^{2\ell})x01′​∈[0,22ℓ)
  • x2′∈[0,2ℓ)x'_2 \in [0, 2^{\ell})x2′​∈[0,2ℓ)
  • w01∈[0,2)w_{01} \in [0, 2)w01​∈[0,2)
  • w2∈[0,2)w_2 \in [0, 2)w2​∈[0,2)

Due to the limited number of copyable witness cells per gate, we are currently only performing this optimization for qqq.

The witness data is

  • q0,q1,q2q_0, q_1, q_2q0​,q1​,q2​
  • q01′,q2′q'_{01}, q'_2q01′​,q2′​
  • qcarry01′,qcarry2′q'_{carry01}, q'_{carry2}qcarry01′​,qcarry2′​

The checks are

  1. q0∈[0,2ℓ)q_0 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q0​∈[0,2ℓ)
  2. q1∈[0,2ℓ)q_1 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q1​∈[0,2ℓ)
  3. q0′=q0+f0′q'_0 = q_0 + f'_0q0′​=q0​+f0′​
  4. q1′=q1+f1′q'_1 = q_1 + f'_1q1′​=q1​+f1′​
  5. s01=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′s_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1s01​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​
  6. q01′∈[0,22ℓ)q'_{01} \in [0, 2^{2\ell})q01′​∈[0,22ℓ)
  7. q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​
  8. qcarry01′∈[0,2)q'_{carry01} \in [0, 2)qcarry01′​∈[0,2)
  9. 22ℓ⋅qcarry01′=s01−q01′2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_{carry01} = s_{01} - q'_{01}22ℓ⋅qcarry01′​=s01​−q01′​
  10. q2∈[0,2ℓ)q_2 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q2​∈[0,2ℓ)
  11. s2=q2+f2′s_2 = q_2 + f'_2s2​=q2​+f2′​
  12. qcarry2′∈[0,2)q'_{carry2} \in [0, 2)qcarry2′​∈[0,2)
  13. 2ℓ⋅qcarry2′=s2+w01−q2′2^{\ell} \cdot q'_{carry2} = s_2 + w_{01} - q'_22ℓ⋅qcarry2′​=s2​+w01​−q2′​

Checks (1) - (5) assure that s01s_{01}s01​ is at most 2ℓ+12\ell + 12ℓ+1 bits. Whereas checks (10) - (11) assure that s2s_2s2​ is at most ℓ+1\ell + 1ℓ+1 bits. Altogether they are comprise a single multi-range-check of q0,q1q_0, q_1q0​,q1​ and q2q_2q2​. However, as noted above, we do not have enough copyable cells to output q1,q2q_1, q_2q1​,q2​ and q3q_3q3​ to the multi-range-check gadget. Therefore, we adopt a strategy where the 2 limbs q01′q'_{01}q01′​ and q2′q'_2q2′​ are output to the multi-range-check gadget where the decomposition of q0′q'_0q0′​ and q2′q'_2q2′​ into q01′=p0+2ℓ⋅p1q'_{01} = p_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot p_1q01′​=p0​+2ℓ⋅p1​ is constrained and then q0′,q1′q'_0, q'_1q0′​,q1′​ and q2′q'_2q2′​ are range checked.

Although q1,q2q_1, q_2q1​,q2​ and q3q_3q3​ are not range checked directly, this is safe because, as shown in the "Bound checks" section, range-checking that q′∈[0,2t)q' \in [0, 2^t)q′∈[0,2t) also constrains that q∈[0,2t)q \in [0, 2^t)q∈[0,2t). Therefore, the updated checks are

  1. q0∈[0,2ℓ)q_0 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q0​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  2. q1∈[0,2ℓ)q_1 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q1​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  3. q0′=q0+f0′q'_0 = q_0 + f'_0q0′​=q0​+f0′​ ForeignFieldMul
  4. q1′=q1+f1′q'_1 = q_1 + f'_1q1′​=q1​+f1′​ ForeignFieldMul
  5. s01=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′s_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1s01​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​ ForeignFieldMul
  6. q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​ multi-range-check
  7. qcarry01′∈[0,2)q'_{carry01} \in [0, 2)qcarry01′​∈[0,2) ForeignFieldMul
  8. 22ℓ⋅qcarry01′=s01−q01′2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_{carry01} = s_{01} - q'_{01}22ℓ⋅qcarry01′​=s01​−q01′​ ForeignFieldMul
  9. q2∈[0,2ℓ)q_2 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q2​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  10. s2=q2+f2′s_2 = q_2 + f'_2s2​=q2​+f2′​ ForeignFieldMul
  11. qcarry2′∈[0,2)q'_{carry2} \in [0, 2)qcarry2′​∈[0,2) ForeignFieldMul
  12. 2ℓ⋅qcarry2′=s2+qcarry01′−q2′2^{\ell} \cdot q'_{carry2} = s_2 + q'_{carry01} - q'_22ℓ⋅qcarry2′​=s2​+qcarry01′​−q2′​ ForeignFieldMul

Note that we don't need to range-check q01′q'_{01}q01′​ is at most 2ℓ+12\ell + 12ℓ+1 bits because it is already implicitly constrained by the multi-range-check gadget constraining that q0′,q1′q'_0, q'_1q0′​,q1′​ and q2′q'_2q2′​ are each at most ℓ\ellℓ bits and that q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​. Furthermore, since constraining the decomposition is already part of the multi-range-check gadget, we do not need to do it here also.

To simplify things further, we can combine some of these checks. Recall our checked computations for the intermediate sums

s01=q01+f01′s2=q2+f2′\begin{aligned} s_{01} &= q_{01} + f'_{01} \\ s_2 &= q_2 + f'_2 \\ \end{aligned}s01​s2​​=q01​+f01′​=q2​+f2′​​

where q01=q0+2ℓ⋅q1q_{01} = q_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q_1q01​=q0​+2ℓ⋅q1​ and f01′=f0′+2ℓ⋅f1′f'_{01} = f'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot f'_1f01′​=f0′​+2ℓ⋅f1′​. These do not need to be separate constraints, but are instead part of existing ones.

Checks (10) and (11) can be combined into a single constraint 2ℓ⋅qcarry2′=(q2+f2′)+qcarry01′−q2′2^{\ell} \cdot q'_{carry2} = (q_2 + f'_2) + q'_{carry01} - q'_22ℓ⋅qcarry2′​=(q2​+f2′​)+qcarry01′​−q2′​. Similarly, checks (3) - (5) and (8) can be combined into 22ℓ⋅qcarry01′=q01+f01′−q01′2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_{carry01} = q_{01} + f'_{01} - q'_{01}22ℓ⋅qcarry01′​=q01​+f01′​−q01′​ with q01q_{01}q01​ and f01′f'_{01}f01′​ further expanded. The reduced constraints are

  1. q0∈[0,2ℓ)q_0 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q0​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  2. q1∈[0,2ℓ)q_1 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q1​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  3. q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​ multi-range-check
  4. qcarry01′∈[0,2)q'_{carry01} \in [0, 2)qcarry01′​∈[0,2) ForeignFieldMul
  5. 22ℓ⋅qcarry01′=s01−q01′2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_{carry01} = s_{01} - q'_{01}22ℓ⋅qcarry01′​=s01​−q01′​ ForeignFieldMul
  6. q2∈[0,2ℓ)q_2 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q2​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  7. qcarry2′∈[0,2)q'_{carry2} \in [0, 2)qcarry2′​∈[0,2) ForeignFieldMul
  8. 2ℓ⋅qcarry2′=s2+w01−q2′2^{\ell} \cdot q'_{carry2} = s_2 + w_{01} - q'_22ℓ⋅qcarry2′​=s2​+w01​−q2′​ ForeignFieldMul

Finally, there is one more optimization that we will exploit. This optimization relies on the observation that for bound addition the second carry bit qcarry2′q'_{carry2}qcarry2′​ is always zero. This this may be obscure, so we will prove it by contradiction. To simplify our work we rename some variables by letting x0=q01x_0 = q_{01}x0​=q01​ and x1=q2x_1 = q_2x1​=q2​. Thus, qcarry2′q'_{carry2}qcarry2′​ being non-zero corresponds to a carry in x1+f1′x_1 + f'_1x1​+f1′​.

Proof: To get a carry in the highest limbs x1+f1′x_1 + f'_1x1​+f1′​ during bound addition, we need

2ℓ<x1+ϕ0+f1′≤2ℓ−1+ϕ0+f1′2^{\ell} < x_1 + \phi_0 + f'_1 \le 2^{\ell} - 1 + \phi_0 + f'_12ℓ<x1​+ϕ0​+f1′​≤2ℓ−1+ϕ0​+f1′​

where 2ℓ−12^{\ell} - 12ℓ−1 is the maximum possible size of x1x_1x1​ (before it overflows) and ϕ0\phi_0ϕ0​ is the overflow bit from the addition of the least significant limbs x0x_0x0​ and f0′f'_0f0′​. This means

2ℓ−ϕ0−f1′<x1<2ℓ2^{\ell} - \phi_0 - f'_1 < x_1 < 2^{\ell}2ℓ−ϕ0​−f1′​<x1​<2ℓ

We cannot allow xxx to overflow the foreign field, so we also have

x1<(f−x0)/22ℓx_1 < (f - x_0)/2^{2\ell}x1​<(f−x0​)/22ℓ

Thus,

2ℓ−ϕ0−f1′<(f−x0)/22ℓ=f/22ℓ−x0/22ℓ2^{\ell} - \phi_0 - f'_1 < (f - x_0)/2^{2\ell} = f/2^{2\ell} - x_0/2^{2\ell}2ℓ−ϕ0​−f1′​<(f−x0​)/22ℓ=f/22ℓ−x0​/22ℓ

Since x0/22ℓ=ϕ0x_0/2^{2\ell} = \phi_0x0​/22ℓ=ϕ0​ we have

2ℓ−ϕ0−f1′<f/22ℓ−ϕ02^{\ell} - \phi_0 - f'_1 < f/2^{2\ell} - \phi_02ℓ−ϕ0​−f1′​<f/22ℓ−ϕ0​

so

2ℓ−f1′<f/22ℓ2^{\ell} - f'_1 < f/2^{2\ell}2ℓ−f1′​<f/22ℓ

Notice that f/22ℓ=f1f/2^{2\ell} = f_1f/22ℓ=f1​. Now we have

2ℓ−f1′<f1⟺f1′>2ℓ−f12^{\ell} - f'_1 < f_1 \\ \Longleftrightarrow \\ f'_1 > 2^{\ell} - f_12ℓ−f1′​<f1​⟺f1′​>2ℓ−f1​

However, this is a contradiction with the definition of our negated foreign field modulus limb f1′=2ℓ−f1f'_1 = 2^{\ell} - f_1f1′​=2ℓ−f1​. ■\blacksquare■

We have proven that qcarry2′q'_{carry2}qcarry2′​ is always zero, so that allows use to simplify our constraints. We now have

  1. q0∈[0,2ℓ)q_0 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q0​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  2. q1∈[0,2ℓ)q_1 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q1​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  3. q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​ multi-range-check
  4. qcarry01′∈[0,2)q'_{carry01} \in [0, 2)qcarry01′​∈[0,2) ForeignFieldMul
  5. 22ℓ⋅qcarry01′=s01−q01′2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_{carry01} = s_{01} - q'_{01}22ℓ⋅qcarry01′​=s01​−q01′​ ForeignFieldMul
  6. q2∈[0,2ℓ)q_2 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q2​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  7. q2′=s2+w01q'_2 = s_2 + w_{01}q2′​=s2​+w01​ ForeignFieldMul

In other words, we have eliminated constraint (7) and removed qcarry2′q'_{carry2}qcarry2′​ from the witness.

Since we already needed to range-check qqq or q′q'q′, the total number of new constraints added is 4: 3 added to ForeignFieldMul and 1 added to multi-range-check gadget for constraining the decomposition of q01′q'_{01}q01′​.

This saves 2 rows per multiplication.

Chaining multiplications​

Due to the limited number of cells accessible to gates, we are not able to chain multiplications into multiplications. We can chain foreign field additions into foreign field multiplications, but currently do not support chaining multiplications into additions (though there is a way to do it).

Constraining the computation​

Now we collect all of the checks that are required to constrain foreign field multiplication

1. Range constrain aaa​

If the aaa operand has not been constrained to [0,f)[0, f)[0,f) by any previous foreign field operations, then we constrain it like this

  • Compute bound a′=a+f′a' = a + f'a′=a+f′ with addition gate (2 rows) ForeignFieldAdd
  • Range check a′∈[0,2t)a' \in [0, 2^t)a′∈[0,2t) (4 rows) multi-range-check

2. Range constrain bbb​

If the bbb operand has not been constrained to [0,f)[0, f)[0,f) by any previous foreign field operations, then we constrain it like this

  • Compute bound b′=b+f′b' = b + f'b′=b+f′ with addition gate (2 rows) ForeignFieldAdd
  • Range check b′∈[0,2t)b' \in [0, 2^t)b′∈[0,2t) (4 rows) multi-range-check

3. Range constrain qqq​

The quotient qqq is constrained to [0,f)[0, f)[0,f) for each multiplication as part of the multiplication gate

  • Compute bound q′=q+f′q' = q + f'q′=q+f′ with ForeignFieldMul constraints
  • Range check q′∈[0,2t)q' \in [0, 2^t)q′∈[0,2t) (4 rows) multi-range-check
  • Range check q≥0q \ge 0q≥0 ForeignFieldMul (implicit by storing q in witness)

4. Range constrain rrr​

The remainder rrr is constrained to [0,f)[0, f)[0,f) for each multiplication using an external addition gate.

  • Compute bound r′=r+f′r' = r + f'r′=r+f′ with addition gate (2 rows) ForeignFieldAdd
  • Range check r′∈[0,2t)r' \in [0, 2^t)r′∈[0,2t) (4 rows) multi-range-check

5. Compute intermediate products​

Compute and constrain the intermediate products p0,p1p_0, p_1p0​,p1​ and p2p_2p2​ as:

  • p0=a0⋅b0+q0⋅f0′p_0 = a_0 \cdot b_0 + q_0 \cdot f'_0p0​=a0​⋅b0​+q0​⋅f0′​ ForeignFieldMul
  • p1=a0⋅b1+a1⋅b0+q0⋅f1′+q1⋅f0′p_1 = a_0 \cdot b_1 + a_1 \cdot b_0 + q_0 \cdot f'_1 + q_1 \cdot f'_0p1​=a0​⋅b1​+a1​⋅b0​+q0​⋅f1′​+q1​⋅f0′​ ForeignFieldMul
  • p2=a0⋅b2+a2⋅b0+a1⋅b1+q0⋅f2′+q2⋅f0′+q1⋅f1′p_2 = a_0 \cdot b_2 + a_2 \cdot b_0 + a_1 \cdot b_1 + q_0 \cdot f'_2 + q_2 \cdot f'_0 + q_1 \cdot f'_1p2​=a0​⋅b2​+a2​⋅b0​+a1​⋅b1​+q0​⋅f2′​+q2​⋅f0′​+q1​⋅f1′​ ForeignFieldMul

where each of them is about 2ℓ2\ell2ℓ-length elements.

6. Native modulus checked computations​

Compute and constrain the native modulus values, which are used to check the constraints modulo nnn in order to apply the CRT

  • an=22ℓ⋅a2+2ℓ⋅a1+a0mod  na_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot a_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot a_1 + a_0 \mod nan​=22ℓ⋅a2​+2ℓ⋅a1​+a0​modn
  • bn=22ℓ⋅b2+2ℓ⋅b1+b0mod  nb_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot b_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot b_1 + b_0 \mod nbn​=22ℓ⋅b2​+2ℓ⋅b1​+b0​modn
  • qn=22ℓ⋅q2+2ℓ⋅q1+q0mod  nq_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot q_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q_1 + q_0 \mod nqn​=22ℓ⋅q2​+2ℓ⋅q1​+q0​modn
  • rn=22ℓ⋅r2+2ℓ⋅r1+r0mod  nr_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot r_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot r_1 + r_0 \mod nrn​=22ℓ⋅r2​+2ℓ⋅r1​+r0​modn
  • fn=22ℓ⋅f2+2ℓ⋅f1+f0mod  nf_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot f_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot f_1 + f_0 \mod nfn​=22ℓ⋅f2​+2ℓ⋅f1​+f0​modn

7. Decompose middle intermediate product​

Check that p1=2ℓ⋅p11+p10p_1 = 2^{\ell} \cdot p_{11} + p_{10}p1​=2ℓ⋅p11​+p10​:

  • p1=2ℓ⋅p11+p10p_1 = 2^\ell \cdot p_{11} + p_{10}p1​=2ℓ⋅p11​+p10​ ForeignFieldMul
  • Range check p10∈[0,2ℓ)p_{10} \in [0, 2^\ell)p10​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  • Range check p11∈[0,2ℓ+2)p_{11} \in [0, 2^{\ell+2})p11​∈[0,2ℓ+2)
    • p11=p111⋅2ℓ+p110p_{11} = p_{111} \cdot 2^\ell + p_{110}p11​=p111​⋅2ℓ+p110​ ForeignFieldMul
    • Range check p110∈[0,2ℓ)p_{110} \in [0, 2^\ell)p110​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
    • Range check p111∈[0,22)p_{111} \in [0, 2^2)p111​∈[0,22) with a degree-4 constraint ForeignFieldMul

8. Zero sum for multiplication​

Now we have to constrain the zero sum

(p0−r0)+288(p1−r1)+2176(p2−r2)=0mod  2t(p_0 - r_0) + 2^{88}(p_1 - r_1) + 2^{176}(p_2 - r_2) = 0 \mod 2^t(p0​−r0​)+288(p1​−r1​)+2176(p2​−r2​)=0mod2t

We constrain the first and the second halves as

  • v0⋅22ℓ=p0+2ℓ⋅p10−r0−2ℓ⋅r1v_0 \cdot 2^{2\ell} = p_0 + 2^\ell \cdot p_{10} - r_0 - 2^\ell \cdot r_1v0​⋅22ℓ=p0​+2ℓ⋅p10​−r0​−2ℓ⋅r1​ ForeignFieldMul
  • v1⋅2ℓ=(p111⋅2ℓ+p110)+p2−r2+v0v_1 \cdot 2^{\ell} = (p_{111} \cdot 2^\ell + p_{110}) + p_2 - r_2 + v_0v1​⋅2ℓ=(p111​⋅2ℓ+p110​)+p2​−r2​+v0​ ForeignFieldMul

And some more range checks

  • Check that v0∈[0,22)v_0 \in [0, 2^2)v0​∈[0,22) with a degree-4 constraint ForeignFieldMul
  • Check that v1∈[0,2ℓ+3)v_1 \in [0, 2^{\ell + 3})v1​∈[0,2ℓ+3)
    • Check v1=v11⋅288+v10v_1 = v_{11} \cdot 2^{88} + v_{10}v1​=v11​⋅288+v10​ ForeignFieldMul
    • Check v11∈[0,23]v_{11} \in [0, 2^3]v11​∈[0,23] ForeignFieldMul
    • Check v10<2ℓv_{10} < 2^\ellv10​<2ℓ with range constraint multi-range-check

To check that v11∈[0,23)v_{11} \in [0, 2^3)v11​∈[0,23) (i.e. that v11v_{11}v11​ is at most 3 bits long) we first range-check v11∈[0,212)v_{11} \in [0, 2^{12})v11​∈[0,212) with a 12-bit plookup. This means there can be no higher bits set beyond the 12-bits of v11v_{11}v11​. Next, we scale v11v_{11}v11​ by 292^929 in order to move the highest 12−3=912 - 3 = 912−3=9 bits beyond the 121212th bit. Finally, we perform a 12-bit plookup on the resulting value. That is, we have

  • Check v11∈[0,212)v_{11} \in [0, 2^{12})v11​∈[0,212) with a 12-bit plookup (to prevent any overflow)
  • Check scaledv11=29⋅v11\mathsf{scaled}_{v_{11}} = 2^9 \cdot v_{11}scaledv11​​=29⋅v11​
  • Check scaledv11\mathsf{scaled}_{v_{11}}scaledv11​​ is a 12-bit value with a 12-bit plookup

Kimchi's plookup implementation is extremely flexible and supports optional scaling of the lookup target value as part of the lookup operation. Thus, we do not require two witness elements, two lookup columns, nor the scaledv11=29⋅v11\mathsf{scaled}_{v_{11}} = 2^9 \cdot v_{11}scaledv11​​=29⋅v11​ custom constraint. Instead we can just store v11v_{11}v11​ in the witness and define this column as a "joint lookup" comprised of one 12-bit plookup on the original cell value and another 12-bit plookup on the cell value scaled by 292^929, thus, yielding a 3-bit check. This eliminates one plookup column and reduces the total number of constraints.

9. Native modulus constraint​

Using the checked native modulus computations we constrain that

an⋅bn−qn⋅fn−rn=0mod  n.a_n \cdot b_n - q_n \cdot f_n - r_n = 0 \mod n.an​⋅bn​−qn​⋅fn​−rn​=0modn.

10. Compute intermediate sums​

Compute and constrain the intermediate sums s01s_{01}s01​ and s2s_2s2​ as:

  • s01=q01+f01′s_{01} = q_{01} + f'_{01}s01​=q01​+f01′​
  • s2=q2+f2′s_2 = q_2 + f_2's2​=q2​+f2′​
  • q01=q0+2ℓ⋅q1q_{01} = q_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q_1q01​=q0​+2ℓ⋅q1​
  • f01′=f0′+2ℓ⋅f1′f'_{01} = f'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot f'_1f01′​=f0′​+2ℓ⋅f1′​

11. Decompose the lower quotient bound​

Check that q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​.

Done by (3) above with the multi-range-check on q′q'q′

  • q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​
  • Range check q0′∈[0,2ℓ)q'_0 \in [0, 2^\ell)q0′​∈[0,2ℓ)
  • Range check q1′∈[0,2ℓ)q'_1 \in [0, 2^\ell)q1′​∈[0,2ℓ)

12. Zero sum for quotient bound addition​

We constrain that

s01−q01′+22ℓ⋅(s2−q2′)=0mod  2ts_{01} - q'_{01} + 2^{2\ell} \cdot (s_2 - q'_2) = 0 \mod 2^ts01​−q01′​+22ℓ⋅(s2​−q2′​)=0mod2t

by constraining the two halves

  • 22ℓ⋅qcarry01′=s01−q01′2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_{carry01} = s_{01} - q'_{01}22ℓ⋅qcarry01′​=s01​−q01′​
  • 2ℓ⋅qcarry2′=s2+qcarry01′−q2′2^{\ell} \cdot q'_{carry2} = s_2 + q'_{carry01} - q'_22ℓ⋅qcarry2′​=s2​+qcarry01′​−q2′​

We also need a couple of small range checks

  • Check that qcarry01′q'_{carry01}qcarry01′​ is boolean ForeignFieldMul
  • Check that q2′q'_2q2′​ is boolean ForeignFieldMul

Layout

Based on the constraints above, we need the following 12 values copied from the range check gates.

a0, a1, a2, b0, b1, b2, q0, q1, q2, r0, r1, r2

Since we need 12 copied values for the constraints, they must span 2 rows.

The q<fq < fq<f bound limbs q0′,q1′q'_0, q'_1q0′​,q1′​ and q2′q'_2q2′​ must be in copyable cells so they can be range-checked. Similarly, the limbs of the operands aaa, bbb and the result rrr must all be in copyable cells. This leaves only 2 remaining copyable cells and, therefore, we cannot compute and output r′=r+f′r' = r + f'r′=r+f′. It must be deferred to an external ForeignFieldAdd gate with the rrr cells copied as an argument.

NB: the fff and f′f'f′ values are publicly visible in the gate coefficients.

Checked computations

As described above foreign field multiplication has the following intermediate computations

  1. p0=a0b0+q0f0′p_0 = a_0b_0 + q_0f'_0p0​=a0​b0​+q0​f0′​
  2. p1=a0b1+a1b0+q0f1′+q1f0′p_1 = a_0b_1 + a_1b_0 + q_0f'_1 + q_1f'_0p1​=a0​b1​+a1​b0​+q0​f1′​+q1​f0′​
  3. p2=a0b2+a2b0+a1b1+q0f2′+q2f0′+q1f1′p_2 = a_0b_2 + a_2b_0 + a_1b_1 + q_0f'_2 + q_2f'_0 + q_1f'_1p2​=a0​b2​+a2​b0​+a1​b1​+q0​f2′​+q2​f0′​+q1​f1′​.

For the qqq bound addition we must also compute

  1. s01=q01+f01′s_{01} = q_{01} + f'_{01}s01​=q01​+f01′​
  2. s2=q2+f2′s_2 = q_2 + f_2's2​=q2​+f2′​
  3. q01=q0+2ℓ⋅q1q_{01} = q_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q_1q01​=q0​+2ℓ⋅q1​
  4. f01′=f0′+2ℓ⋅f1′f'_{01} = f'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot f'_1f01′​=f0′​+2ℓ⋅f1′​

Note the equivalence

s01=q01+f01′=q0+2ℓ⋅q1+f0′+2ℓ⋅f1′=q0+f0′+2ℓ⋅(q1′+f1′)=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′\begin{aligned} s_{01} &= q_{01} + f'_{01} \\ &= q_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q_1 + f'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot f'_1 \\ &= q_0 + f'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot (q'_1 + f'_1) \\ &= q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1 \end{aligned}s01​​=q01​+f01′​=q0​+2ℓ⋅q1​+f0′​+2ℓ⋅f1′​=q0​+f0′​+2ℓ⋅(q1′​+f1′​)=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​​

where q0′=q0+f0′q'_0 = q_0 + f'_0q0′​=q0​+f0′​ and q1′=q1+f1′q'_1 = q_1 + f'_1q1′​=q1​+f1′​ can be done with checked computations.

Next, for applying the CRT we compute

  1. an=22ℓ⋅a2+2ℓ⋅a1+a0mod  na_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot a_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot a_1 + a_0 \mod nan​=22ℓ⋅a2​+2ℓ⋅a1​+a0​modn
  2. bn=22ℓ⋅b2+2ℓ⋅b1+b0mod  nb_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot b_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot b_1 + b_0 \mod nbn​=22ℓ⋅b2​+2ℓ⋅b1​+b0​modn
  3. qn=22ℓ⋅q2+2ℓ⋅q1+q0mod  nq_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot q_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q_1 + q_0 \mod nqn​=22ℓ⋅q2​+2ℓ⋅q1​+q0​modn
  4. rn=22ℓ⋅r2+2ℓ⋅r1+r0mod  nr_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot r_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot r_1 + r_0 \mod nrn​=22ℓ⋅r2​+2ℓ⋅r1​+r0​modn
  5. fn=22ℓ⋅f2+2ℓ⋅f1+f0mod  nf_n = 2^{2\ell} \cdot f_2 + 2^{\ell} \cdot f_1 + f_0 \mod nfn​=22ℓ⋅f2​+2ℓ⋅f1​+f0​modn

Checks

In total we require the following checks

  1. p111∈[0,22)p_{111} \in [0, 2^2)p111​∈[0,22)
  2. v10∈[0,2ℓ)v_{10} \in [0, 2^{\ell})v10​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  3. p110∈[0,2ℓ)p_{110} \in [0, 2^{\ell})p110​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  4. p10∈[0,2ℓ)p_{10} \in [0, 2^{\ell})p10​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  5. p11=2ℓ⋅p111+p110p_{11} = 2^{\ell} \cdot p_{111} + p_{110}p11​=2ℓ⋅p111​+p110​
  6. p1=2ℓ⋅p11+p10p_1 = 2^{\ell} \cdot p_{11} + p_{10}p1​=2ℓ⋅p11​+p10​
  7. v0∈[0,22)v_0 \in [0, 2^2)v0​∈[0,22)
  8. 22ℓ⋅v0=p0+2ℓ⋅p10−r0−2ℓ⋅r12^{2\ell} \cdot v_0 = p_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot p_{10} - r_0 - 2^{\ell} \cdot r_122ℓ⋅v0​=p0​+2ℓ⋅p10​−r0​−2ℓ⋅r1​
  9. v11∈[0,23)v_{11} \in [0, 2^{3})v11​∈[0,23)
  10. v1=2ℓ⋅v11+v10v_1 = 2^{\ell} \cdot v_{11} + v_{10}v1​=2ℓ⋅v11​+v10​
  11. 2ℓ⋅v1=v0+p11+p2−r22^{\ell} \cdot v_1 = v_0 + p_{11} + p_2 - r_22ℓ⋅v1​=v0​+p11​+p2​−r2​
  12. an⋅bn−qn⋅fn=rna_n \cdot b_n - q_n \cdot f_n = r_nan​⋅bn​−qn​⋅fn​=rn​
  13. q0′∈[0,2ℓ)q'_0 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q0′​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  14. q1′∈[0,2ℓ)q'_1 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q1′​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  15. q2′∈[0,2ℓ)q'_2 \in [0, 2^{\ell})q2′​∈[0,2ℓ) multi-range-check
  16. q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​ multi-range-check
  17. qcarry01′∈[0,2)q'_{carry01} \in [0, 2)qcarry01′​∈[0,2)
  18. 22ℓ⋅qcarry01′=s01−q01′2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_{carry01} = s_{01} - q'_{01}22ℓ⋅qcarry01′​=s01​−q01′​
  19. q2′=s2+qcarry01′q'_2 = s_2 + q'_{carry01}q2′​=s2​+qcarry01′​

Constraints

These checks can be condensed into the minimal number of constraints as follows.

First, we have the range-check corresponding to (1) as a degree-4 constraint

C1: p111⋅(p111−1)⋅(p111−2)⋅(p111−3)p_{111} \cdot (p_{111} - 1) \cdot (p_{111} - 2) \cdot (p_{111} - 3)p111​⋅(p111​−1)⋅(p111​−2)⋅(p111​−3)

Checks (2) - (4) are all handled by a single multi-range-check gadget.

C2: multi-range-check v10,p10,p110v_{10}, p_{10}, p_{110}v10​,p10​,p110​

Next (5) and (6) can be combined into

C3: 2ℓ⋅(2ℓ⋅p111+p110)+p10=p12^{\ell} \cdot (2^{\ell} \cdot p_{111} + p_{110}) + p_{10} = p_12ℓ⋅(2ℓ⋅p111​+p110​)+p10​=p1​

Now we have the range-check corresponding to (7) as another degree-4 constraint

C4: v0⋅(v0−1)⋅(v0−2)⋅(v0−3)v_0 \cdot (v_0 - 1) \cdot (v_0 - 2) \cdot (v_0 - 3)v0​⋅(v0​−1)⋅(v0​−2)⋅(v0​−3)

Next we have check (8)

C5: 22ℓ⋅v0=p0+2ℓ⋅p10−r0−2ℓ⋅r12^{2\ell} \cdot v_0 = p_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot p_{10} - r_0 - 2^{\ell} \cdot r_122ℓ⋅v0​=p0​+2ℓ⋅p10​−r0​−2ℓ⋅r1​

Up next, check (9) is a 3-bit range check

C6: Plookup v11v_{11}v11​ (12-bit plookup scaled by 292^929)

Now checks (10) and (11) can be combined into

C7: 2ℓ⋅(v11⋅2ℓ+v10)=p2+p11+v0−r22^{\ell} \cdot (v_{11} \cdot 2^{\ell} + v_{10}) = p_2 + p_{11} + v_0 - r_22ℓ⋅(v11​⋅2ℓ+v10​)=p2​+p11​+v0​−r2​

Next, for our use of the CRT, we must constrain that a⋅b=q⋅f+rmod  na \cdot b = q \cdot f + r \mod na⋅b=q⋅f+rmodn. Thus, check (12) is

C8: an⋅bn−qn⋅fn=rna_n \cdot b_n - q_n \cdot f_n = r_nan​⋅bn​−qn​⋅fn​=rn​

Next we must constrain the quotient bound addition.

Checks (13) - (16) are all combined into multi-range-check gadget

C9: multi-range-check q0′,q1′,q2′q'_0, q'_1, q'_2q0′​,q1′​,q2′​ and q01′=q0′+2ℓ⋅q1′q'_{01} = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} \cdot q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓ⋅q1′​.

Check (17) is a carry bit boolean check

C10: qcarry01′⋅(qcarry01′−1)q'_{carry01} \cdot (q'_{carry01} - 1)qcarry01′​⋅(qcarry01′​−1)

Next, check (18) is

C11: 22ℓ⋅qcarry10′=s01−q01′2^{2\ell} \cdot q'_{carry10} = s_{01} - q'_{01}22ℓ⋅qcarry10′​=s01​−q01′​

Finally, check (19) is

C12: q2′=s2+qcarry01′q'_2 = s_2 + q'_{carry01}q2′​=s2​+qcarry01′​

The Zero gate has no constraints and is just used to hold values required by the ForeignFieldMul gate.

External checks

The following checks must be done with other gates to assure the soundness of the foreign field multiplication

  • Range check input
    • multi-range-check aaa
    • multi-range-check bbb
  • Range check witness data
    • multi-range-check q′q'q′ and check q01′=q0′+2ℓq1′q_{01}' = q'_0 + 2^{\ell} q'_1q01′​=q0′​+2ℓq1′​
    • multi-range-check ℓ\ellℓ-bit limbs: p10,p110,p111p_{10}, p_{110}, p_{111}p10​,p110​,p111​
  • Range check output
    • multi-range-check either rrr or r′r'r′
  • Compute and constrain r′r'r′ the bound on rrr
    • ForeignFieldAdd r+2t=1⋅f+r′r + 2^t = 1 \cdot f + r'r+2t=1⋅f+r′

Copy constraints must connect the above witness cells to their respective input cells within the corresponding external check gates witnesses.
